<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 301, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 446]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 504, 461]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 504, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 380, 490]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 255, 515]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 361, 530]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 560]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 604, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 757, 600]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 636, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 621, 121]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 537, 579, 556]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
A chest expander is a piece of equipment used by athletes in a gym. Fig. 2.1 shows a chest expander that consists of five identical springs connected in parallel between two handles.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 222, 740, 388]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 403, 532, 422]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 435, 561, 454]]<|/det|>
Each spring has an unstretched length of \(0.63 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 466, 920, 501]]<|/det|>
Two athletes are stretching the chest expander by pulling on the two handles in opposite directions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 513, 181, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 513, 448, 532]]<|/det|>
The springs obey Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 543, 529, 562]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 666, 180, 685]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 666, 757, 685]]<|/det|>
Each athlete pulls the handle towards himself with a force of 1300 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 698, 500, 716]]<|/det|>
1. State the tension in each spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[509, 758, 920, 777]]<|/det|>
<form>tension = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 790, 777, 809]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 821, 616, 841]]<|/det|>
Calculate the spring constant \(k\) of each spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 914, 920, 933]]<|/det|>
<form>k = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 914, 920, 933]]<|/det|>

<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The resistance of a \(1.0 \text{m}\) length of resistance wire is \(7.6 \Omega\). A length of this wire is taped to a metre rule. A crocodile clip is connected to one end of the resistance wire exactly at the \(0 \text{m}\) mark of the rule. Fig. 7.1 shows the crocodile clip connected to terminal P.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[32, 128, 965, 339]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 355, 532, 373]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
A second terminal Q is connected to a movable contact using a long length of connecting wire. The movable contact is in contact with the resistance wire at a length \(l\) from the \(0 \text{m}\) mark on the rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 448, 920, 482]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 732, 91]]<|/det|>
Fig. 8.1 shows a ray of red light incident on one side of a glass prism in air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 504, 363]]<|/det|>
For red light, the refractive index of glass is \(n_{\mathrm{R}}\).
